I love this game. I can already say it is the best theme park game i ever played.  This game is so great because it is limitless in regards to building and creativity. The amount of themes looks okay but once you start combining items from other themes together you can basically make any theme you can imagine. Lovely graphics, art design and the detail is extraordinary and looks so realistic.  There is a good amount of Flat rides, a great amount of Coasters, 2 Transport rides and they even added some water rides like the log flumes and river rapids. You can also make Darkrides and there are options to set trigger events to your rides and coasters. For those who like their own music better then the ingame music, wich is great, you can add custom music to the rides and speakers.  The park management is very in-depth and allows you to do just about everything you need as a park manager.  My final verdict (based on theme park games): 10/10

I will put together a better review once I have been able to play Planet Coaster for longer.  For now I have to highly recommend this game based only on the 4.5h I have played in a sandbox map to see how the custom roller coaster creation has evolved since the now ancient roller coaster tycoon 1 & 2 [witch I still class as some of my favourite games].  It's a huge jump, looks a little overwhelming to start with, the grid system of old has gone allowing for every corner to be as you set it. There are a large number of loops, inversions, and pre set banking's, but even after you have placed these you can adjust there size, width and angle to attached track. With the inclusion of an autocomplete and snap to function you will easily be able to finish the track. You can also test the track as you are building it allowing for tweaks as you build helping to prevent scenarios like too high loops that would cause the ride to fail.  Big + You can ride your coaster from any seat or even a more cinematic view. Never going to a theme park again now I can ride my own coasters.  From what else I have seen the management side [research, staffing and so on] it is somewhat on the basic side, like the games before, but this is far from a negative point it's enough to customise what you need without taking too much from the focus of building a park how you want it.  I will easily be spending 100's of hours on this just creating coasters.  My hat goes off to the development team, you have made an amazing game.

I love this game. I can already say it is up there with the original Roller Coaster Tycoon and Theme Hospital as one of my favourite management games ever.   In terms of gameplay, the game provides sufficient depth. You can manage your staff (training, area and task allocation); your rides (building, maintenance, themes, refurbishment, priority queues); and high level management such marketing campaigns and finances. There's definitely more that escapes me. With that said, I think there is room to add more depth and mechanics to the game in future DLC.  You can make some really good-looking parks thanks to the game's great graphics and also the multitude of scenery and prop items you can place. The game allows you to build sophisticated scenes by letting you place various props on top of each other, and creating a sort of story for an area. In the pirate themed scenarios (the only scenarios I've played so far), you can make use of scaffoldings, ship wrecks (I'm talking multi-level hull wreckage), barrels and animated characters such as pirates and guards to create skirmish scenes.   Speaking of animated props, you can tie those to triggers which are arbitrarily placed on ride tracks to make for awesome events. They aren't just for looks either; they will boost the appeal of the ride and will also make things more interesting for guests that are waiting in queues. If you take the effort to do this, guests won't mind waiting 10 minutes in the queue.   The only thing that worries me is the amount of content. The game supports Steam Workshop, but it doesn't look like there are scenarios on the workshop. The game has 12 scenarios which I don't think will take me more than 20-30 hours.

After the disappointing Roller Coaster Tycoon World announcement there seemed to really be no hope for the Coaster Tycoon Genre. As RCT World kept getting passed around developers like a cheap hooker the outlook grew dimmer and dimmer.  But the developers that brought us RCT2 DLC and RCT3 and its DLC were already working on a new title. Planet Coaster. And a promising looking one at that. And boy have I been having fun with this game. If I had to use one word to describe this game's greatest aspect it would have to be Freedom. The way the game lets you take total control on how you want to build is fantastic, the terrain and building tools are simple to use and extremely effective at creating exactly what you wanted to create. The fact that you are allowed to clip scenery and buildings into terrain and each other already frees you up to use the given tools in so many creative ways.  Really the only issues I have with this game are small quality of life problems.  If you enjoyed RCT3 this is pretty much a must buy, it is well worth the price.

TL;DR: This game is absolutely fantstic, and the people who made it are fantastic.  (Full disclosure, I won this game in a giveaway contest, but still would've paid full price for it had I not won the giveaway)  Long version: This game is to the 'Rollercoaster Tycoon' series what 'Cities Skylines' is for the 'Simcity' Series.  PROS: (Too many to list, honestly. I'll try to mention the big ones that come to mind.) -First of all it's FUN. Very fun. Very very fun, and a great heir to the RCT throne, to the point where I don't see myself going back to older RCT games for any reason other than nostalgia or just to try their scenarios again. -It has both a managment aspect and a sandbox aspect. -The graphics are BEAUTIFUL -Wonderfully realistic roller coasters -Buildings and track pieces are not restricted to a grid, allowing for flowing shapes and much more realistic parks than any other game, yet grids do exist, they only pop up while constructing buildings, though, and can be edited fairly easily. -The UI makes it so it's friendly to both pedantic coaster geeks(such as myself) who want to build overly realistic, high detail amusement parks, while also being friendly to the genereal public player who doesn't want to build the next disneyland but just wants to putter around and build a nice little, possibly unrealistic amusement park. -Sandbox and the ability to build whatever construction you can think of pretty much give this game years of replayability. If modding support ever happens, this could easily live as long as RCT2 and RCT3 did. -The attention to detail is staggering. From guest animations, to the things you can micromanage, it's all wonderful. -One of the most versatile, yet user friendly editors in any game I've ever seen. You can build insanely detailed and intricate ride layouts or buildings fairly easily. -I can't stress this enough: The developers are a FANTASTIC bunch and I've never seen game devs this closely involved in their community. Whenver something bothered us and we'd post about it on the forums, it would get fixed. Features planned for the game (Such as Go Karts) were delayed because they saw the community had other features they wanted to see on release (such as water rides). They took everything we liked about RCT3 and kept it, and took everything we didn't like about RCT3 and fixed it. They are wonderful and I definitely encourage supporting them by buying this game. Good game dev-community relationships should be rewarded.  CONS: -Because of how detailed all the rides are... Ride selection is unfortunately small. More will be released in the future, I'm sure, but it would've been nice to have more to begin with. Some fairly basic rides are still missing from the game. -So is the number of Scenarios (12 secnarios overall. They're more challenging than I expected, and I've yet to finish them all, but still would've liked more!) -No scenario editor. -Some rides have built-in theming, and don't have generic alternatives. Most rides are generic but it would still be nice to have generic versions for more of them. -At the time of writing this there isn't any mod support yet, nor do I know if any is planned. -Various minor issues here and there such as a minor bug or a less-convenient feature. Mostly they're pretty harmless and get fixed when noticed by the devs.  Conclusion: If you like amusement park building-and-managing games, you absolutely can't ask for a better one. Replayability will depend on how creative you are. If you're not very creative, playability will probably end once you finish all the scenarios, at least until they release an expansion pack of some sort. If you ARE creative and enjoy building creative things - sandbox mode alone can keep you playing for years on end. The game isn't perfect, but it's as close as I've ever seen an amusement park game get!

TL;DR  This game is a worthy successor to the previous RCT games, and is worth picking up! The possibilities are endless.  My experience with the Rollercoaster Tycoon games has been inconsistent at best. I got the first game out of a cereal box, never played career mode, and focused mainly on building rides that would kill people. I skipped two, forgot about the series, and eventually picked up RCT3, where I ignored ride and park building, and mainly wasted time building groups of me and my friends and following them around. I proceeded to forget about the series once again.  But when a youtuber I follow started doing videos on Planet Coaster a couple of weeks before it's release, showcasing the creative freedom the game gave you and just how far Frontier's physics engine has come since the first RCT game, I couldn't help but get interested in the sandbox and park management genre again, in a way I never have before.  My few hours in the game so far (almost four at the time of writing this) have been spent mostly in the sandbox, getting used to the controls and playing with the landscaping tools to see what was possible. Today however, I started the career mode scenarios, and started to get into the gritty details of park building.  There's so much possibility in Planet Coaster. The blueprints created by other players in the Steam Workshop are a huge example of this. It's fun to play, easy to get into and customize, and a worthy successor to the RCT name. If you have the time, are interested in playing a management and building sim, or remember the original RCT and wonder where the creators ended up, pick this game up and give it a go!

Planet Coaster is the Roller Coaster Tycoon 3 sequel we all deserve. Planet Coaster improves the graphics and look of RCT3 and builds on its successes by giving us exceptional management tools and a huge box of content to be as creative and innovative as never before.   What makes Planet Coaster such a complete amusement park sim is that the developers did is tested out a small portion of the game little by little perfecting each system before releasing it in entirety. Terrain editor, staff, park, guest, ride management and scenary editor are all top notch and are perfect. Physics engine and riding the rides are better than ever before. Although, to be stuck building coasters and other tracks piece by piece instead of similar to Roller Coaster Tycoon World's spline system, seems like one step backwards.   Planet Coaster is easy to play, and it's a beautiful game. It looks like a game that was released in 2016. It's fun, and the options of how to make a park are endless. Only more content will come to this already massive game. There are so few things to say negatively about Planet Coaster. If you're just joining the genre, this game can be a bit scary since it doesn't really offer any tutorial to learn the ropes. But the game is not difficult to figure out.   Planet Coaster's success is built on the developers from Frontier who built RCT3 and they know what they're doing. It joins a list of successful park simulation games and offers a lot of fun and one of the (if not the) best choices for the greatest simulations out there. One gripe for me and I'm sure a lot of players out there is performance. You need a high end graphics card as well as a top level processor to run the game at an acceptable framerate with all your park content. Still, the performance is not a game breaker even if you have a lower rig. You can still enjoy all hours of time invested into this masterpiece.

Great ride building, decorating, and management. This is not just a rollercoaster building game, but a full blown theme park management game like the ones we grew up with.   The rollercoaster builder is intuitive and easy to use while having very few restrictions, allowing the shape and direction of every piece to be adjusted before placing it. You'll need to actually make a good ride for people to enjoy it by making sure the turns are banked and that the car is not traveling too fast over bumps, and of course making sure it's not boring.  The campaign and challenge modes require you to balance your budget. You'll need to place shops, research new items, advertise, and pay back loans while trying to keep guests happy. There is also a sandbox mode that allows you to ignore all this and just build with no restrictions.  Decorating your park will likely consume half your time if you're into it, though the game makes the process simple. Placing objects is very easy with the tools provided, allowing you to freely place objects, snap them to a grid, and/or use an option to move objects along an axis for finer tweaking.  The visuals are appealing and the lighting effects look very nice. A lot of detail went into the assets like high-quality textures and creative animations. It's easy to tell if people are happy or not, like your janitors humming and twirling their brooms if they're getting paid well.  It's a little lacking in some content. There's about all you could want for rollercoaster types, but lacking in pre-built rides. Things like go-karts and boats are missing if you compare it to RCT. Unfortunately the game lacks modding, everything on the Workshop is just buildings and rides made in-game. Can only hope new content is delivered through free updates or full expansion packs and not microtransactions for each piece of content.   The game also has some performance problems as your park grows. It's CPU dependent and it will eventually become sluggish for players even with the highest end processors. This is unfortunately in the nature of a modern management simulation game where everyone is calculated.  We were all excited about the announcement of a new RollerCoaster Tycoon, but it took someone else to actually deliver. This is the one to buy if you're interested in a new full experience entry to the genre.

To preface the review: I absolutely love the game and have been thoroughly addicted to it since owning it. That being said it has quite a lot of problems that may put some people off, I won't mention some of the things that a lot of people have already talked about, but more about the business side of things which has been vastly expanded over past RCT games. Also, I should say that I have put hundreds, if not thousands of hours into old RCT games (2&3 especially) and my favourite thing has always been designing roller coasters.  I'm sure you read other reviews, and if you haven't go and read them for the positive points (even though I am giving this game a positivie review, I would like to spend more time on the problems as I think that these are less documented than the good parts of the games). I want to give myself more time to talk about the bugs and problems with the games. So to quickly summarise: I think that this is a fantastically improved RCT 3 sequel, it took everything I liked about that game and expanded it greatly, especially in the terms of building and micro management.  Now onto the problems/bugs: -- One of the biggest problems at the moment is the poor framerates in parks with a lot of assests and/or guests, and especially when you're building things. My computer is not amazing (i5 3570k, 16gb ram, gtx 1060 6gb) but I only get as low as >5 fps when building in a park with more than 5,000 guests, and around >20 when not building ON THE LOWEST GRAPHICAL SETTINGS. I have read people on the forums with dual 1080s and OC top of the line CPUs getting 15-20 fps in similar scenarios: this definitely seems to be a problem with how the game is optimised, as when you start a park I get a solid 120fps on medium settings. You end up having to limit the amount of guests in your park, which defeats the point of building a bigger and better park for more people to come and spend money at. Developers have acknowledged and promised to fix this, but as of this review nothing has improved and people have claimed that FPS has actually gotten worse while constructing roller coasters.  -- The business side of the game is really lacking, the scenarios are all built around small parks that you need to fulfill a number of financial challenges to complete, but they all seem pretty easy once you work out the game's weird way of evaluating things (that are never explained). For example people go to different parts of the park for rides but not for shops, so you have to position shops right beside them or else they could be dying of thirst and not walk 10 steps out of their way to buy a drink for the shop around the corner. Also the coaster ratings (that define the worth of the ride) don't seem to correlate much with real life, there's a roller coaster on the workshop that just does one drop into an upside corner and turns back into the station. This ride costs $2050 and will make you at least that in a month, but spend $50,000 on a custom roller coaster that takes you an hour to build and it will only get you $3000-6000 a month only with you painstakingly making sure every part of the track is compliant with the arbitary rating system. If you build something realistic (I modeled a dive coaster after Valravn) then it's more than likely that the stats are going to be pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥. This all ties into the game's lack of instruction of how to make things better, and it's not always apparent. Park layout, the amount of shops for the guests, and the amount that guests are willing to pay for things (and what effects that) are never explained and nigh on impossible to work out without a lot of experimentation if at all. Also, like other people have mentioned: once you get over that first hurdle of profitability then there really is no challenge, you will just make money like there's no tomorrow! It feels like you are rewarded for working out the weird way the game works instead of building a beautiful and interesting theme park. This is better than the old games, granted, but still needs some improvement to create more challenege and more reward for your hard work.  -- The roller coaster designer is very powerful but it feels like you have to fight it in order to make smooth rides, and it also has a number of bugs/quirks to it. Like often if I make a number of roller coasters in one sitting then the ride option goes away until I restart the game. Also if you bank your track too slowly (using the in built smoothing option) then you often end up with jerky banking animations going between the sections of tracks. You need the smoothing tool to make a coaster that is anywhere close to smooth and that has good stats, but the smoothing tool also likes to destroy and of your own custom inversions, and the ones that come with the game are very limiting.  So there's a summary of the biggest problems I have with the game, there are a number of smaller problems like guests thinking that a queue is full when it clearly isn't, and trains on roller coasters getting stuck, but these aren't huge game limiting problems like the ones mentioned above (although that's obviously just my opinion). I hope that the developers will continue with support for the game, fixing these problems and introducing expansions like RCT (waterpark and animals would be amazing!).  Overall an amazing game for lovers of RCT 3 like me, but it has it's problems that may put off some.

I do see why some are saying the campaign is too easy, this is somewhat true, so just knock it out and do a hard mode challenge, trust me you'll find it fulfilling.   Also, theres plenty of rides, I'd say 20+ small rides, 7 or so track rides, 15+ different coaster types.

This is based on Sandbox mode in the beta, which the developers have said is nearly feature-complete.  Planet Coaster is a good game, but the more time I spent with it, the more things I noticed were missing from previous games, or even just things that should be that weren't. Missing pieces of scenery sets, fewer rides and shops than RollerCoaster Tycoon, a frustrating pathing system, and entire coaster options of different cars and launch options are missing. The UI is a sore spot as well, giving you tools for micromanagement but nothing to make macromanagement easier.  The rollercoasters are the heart of the game, and though design is intuitive and fun, the rating system is a bit frustrating. Each track piece is assigned an Excitement/Fear/Nausea rating, with fast drops increasing Excitement and Fear, and unbanked turns raising Nausea. They're essentially the Excitement/Intensity/Nausea from RCT. The overall rating of the coaster is based on the overall -average- of each track piece, and it's where problems crop up. Slowing down a fast coaster with brakes to create tension before a drop isn't reflected in game, and you're given a low Excitement rating for having low speed before a drop, dragging your overall rating down. The coaster rating system takes a while to get used to after years of RCT, and the friction feels tuned too high to feel confident in predicting speed - oftentimes I've had to add drive tires to my coaster to keep it going just a few pieces after a lift hill. Heatmaps showing you the most nauseating and most exciting parts of your ride are useful, though a bit limited in application around areas with brakes.  Coaster design is the main draw to Planet Coaster, and it does it well. The designer allows full angle control of each piece horizontally and vertically, along with full control down to the degree a piece is banked at. The familiar chain lift speed, block brake, and loop-de-loops are there, along with Norwegian loops, bowtie loops, banana rolls, and just about everything that comes up under 'Rollercoaster Elements' on Wikipedia. There's 28 base rollercoasters, including floorless, launch, seated, inverted, standup, giga, and wooden coasters. Unfortunately, Boomerang/Shuttleloop-type coasters are missing, and car-type is decided by coaster rather than having multiple options. Friction is, again, tuned a bit high, forcing you to make larger and bigger-scale coasters compared to RCT. Overall, the designer is intuitive and easy to grasp, and the angle-snap button allows you to move pieces in precise increments of 15 degrees to make it even easier.  Staff and park management is frustrating, with plenty of micromanagement options right down to how much of a condiment you want on a shop's burgers, but little room for macromanagement. Individual staff members can be trained and given raises down to the dollar, but there's no way to simply train your staff to a higher level whenever they're ready and give them an appropriate raise automatically, or even train more than one employee at a time. Syncing shop prices and condiments across a park is bizzarely missing from Frontier's previous RCT3, forcing you to go through however many burger or drink stands you have to make sure they're the same price, same toppings, same settings on each. Hiring staff is a sluggish process of hitting the park management window, waiting a few seconds, hiring and placing staff, then repeating this process beceause the management screen closes after hiring. If your staff aren't given the proper wages, they'll also have a mood debuff, and might even quit on you, wasting their training.  The game is strongest in coaster building and scenery. There's hundreds of scenery pieces with a wide array of animatronics and props from fairytale dragons to dying aliens, from castle walls to metal alloy roofs. These pieces can be combined in nearly limitless ways, though most walls and roofs can't be rotated freely. Thankfully, light fixtures, doors, windows, and most non-building scenery options -can- be rotated freely through 3-axes. Though some pieces of certain scenery sets are missing, it's easy enough to take advantage of the no-clip scenery and simply fake what you can by throwing together a few smaller pieces (NOTE: This may have been fixed in launch, I didn't check every piece yet). Once you've finished, you can save a building as a blueprint, scenery and all, and share it to the Steam Workshop. For those not creatively inclined, this means you can just search for what you want and download it and place it or modify it within seconds in-game.  Terrain sculpting is another high point. Pulling, pushing, roughening, and smoothing terrain is simple, though sheer cliff faces are near-impossible. Checkboxes for whether the terrain should respect scenery and form around it, or just ignore it, means sculpting a tunnel around a pre-built coaster or making an underground ride is easy.  Flat ride selection suffers outside of coasters, especially in theming. If you want a scifi version of some rides like swinging ships, you're out of luck. If you want bumper cars? Nope. Elevators and chairlifts? Sorry, main transport is monorails. There's classics like merry-go-rounds, gyro swings, and ferris wheels, but it lacks in the smaller rides like hedge mazes and haunted houses. There's not a lot of room for small, 'local' parks in Planet Coaster. Everything is big, up-to-date with electronics and flashing lights. It can feel a bit too pristine. Water ride selection similarily suffers, though the log flume and river rapids covers the fan favorites.  Overall, Planet Coaster is a pretty good sandbox game, maybe even a great one. Many of the annoyances with management fade away with unlimited money, and there's never been anything better when it comes to scenery and coaster design, especially with the blueprint sharing system. The detail and polish to what rides are there and the coasters are fantastic, and the personality to the game is just as bubbly as a theme park game should be. Where the game suffers most is in the actual management system and in ride selection. Though difficult to live up to RCT1/2/3, the UI feels sluggish when it comes to staff and park management, and the tedious process of staff wages and training seems so obviously unoptimized it makes you wonder if it's intentional. It's not unplayable by any means, but it does put a damper on what should be a better experience. However, a big advantage Planet Coaster has is developers that clearly care about the game and are willing to update and keep optimizing the game to be better, and even what's now slightly tedious has come a long way from Alpha and Beta.

You're used to this story by now, the industry has trained us to buy games that aren't complete.   If the question is: Is this the RCT3 sequel I've been waiting for? The answer is: It totally will be in a year, and hopefully we won't have to pay more for it.  In short, the core game is here, and fantastic. It is absolutely the true successor to the rollercoaster tycoon series. The bad news is it's got 20% of the content it should, and is the very clear product of a community of alpha testers who were primarily interested in their favorite pet coaster and elaborate, hyper-detailed scenery and building options.  But the game doesn't even have as many rides in TOTAL as RCT3 shipped with in each CATEGORY of ride. There are a fair number of coasters but several of them are just duplicates of one another with minor variants, and there still aren't as many as shipped with previous tycoon games.  The management is even more rudimentary than RCT3 and offers precisely zero innovations, the career campaign is as identically bland and forgettable as old games, and in many cases the interface is actually a step back, although they're tweaking it bit by bit. Oh, and that revolutionary 'guest brain' they spent so much time hyping in marketing? You'll just have to take their word for it that it's under there, somewhere. Because parks operate, and guests react, identically to the way they did in RCT3. There are absolutely no visible signs of this 'simulation evolved' nonsense they kept going on about. It's RCT3 with better graphics and less functionality right now, straight up.  The game shouldn't have gone full release yet, it deserved and required another 6 months of development dedicated solely to expanding features and content. But the devs have promised heavy post-release support before pursuing paid DLCs, so we can hope that in a year's time they'll have actually completed the game and we can finally enjoy the next rollercoaster tycoon in all its glory.  The degree to which you want to be upset about this shortcoming is up to you. I'm fine with it, but only on the promise that they'll actually complete the game now that they've sold it to me.  But don't believe the fanboys raving about how it's already perfect. They're so dedicated to supporting the game that they're willing to lie to themselves and tell each other stories about 'omg how hard it is to make a game in 2016 compared to 20 years ago we should be so grateful we have what we do,' which is patent ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. The devs built a very solid core game then skipped the second half of development in favor of releasing it to the paying market, and it shows. But it's likely to only change for the better as time goes on. I fully expect to be updating this review to an unconditional 'recommend' within 12 months.
